In vitro fertilisation is the fertilisation of the egg outside of the womb and then the implantation of the developing foetus into it. The egg can be that of the mother, in the case of blocked fallopian tubes or post-fertility treatment, but is often donated or even taken from an aborted foetus. It is often the only way that people can have children if they are infertile, and the moral dilemmas it causes are contentious issues.

In vitro fertilisation has given women who are unable to have children this opportunity. Being declared infertile used to prevent all hope of this, but the advance in technology has made many people very happy. It is the whole purpose of our species, in some people's view, to reproduce and this discovery has given this opportunity to many more women. However, in response to this, many people see it as going against nature. This is not natural for fertilisation to take place outside the womb, and in some people's views, the whole idea goes against God and nature. In fact, they believe that in vitro treatment is "playing God." I believe that women who use their own egg for having a test tube baby have every right to do so. Those who have someone else's egg with consent should have the same rights.

Another problem with having a test tube baby could arise from the egg donation. If an egg is donated by a friend, the donor could want rights over a child whom they may see as their own. A child who was a test tube baby may grow up with identity problems due to this. A particularly bad example of this relates to eggs taken from aborted fetuses. A child growing up with the knowledge of having come from an aborted fetus, something which has never technically been alive, could be left with psychological problems. This should be better regulated.

This treatment is costly. On the NHS, treatment costs could be used to fund more life-saving treatments rather than to bring more children into an overpopulated world. There are many children who are unwanted and who need adopting. Stricter guidelines on in vitro fertilisation and an easing of the adoption process could help a lot of unwanted children.

In the 1960's and 1970's, cows were given feed which included sheep (and their brains) in its ingredients. Many animals which ate this feed developed BSE and even more passed it on to their young.
There is a belief among the people of the UK that eating beef is dangerous, as they believe that the BSE can be passed on to humans when they eat beef. Pictures on the television of cows with BSE who are unable to walk properly and humans with CJD highlight how horrific and debilitating a condition CJD is. If the media coverage of CJD and BSE continues in the same manner, it is not inconceivable that people in the UK might be so scared that they cease to eat beef entirely.
If people in the UK were to cease to eat beef, the effect on the agricultural industry would be devestating. Cow farmers would fall in numbers by a huge amount. This is because with the beef market destroyed, the only market open to these farmers would be the dairy products market which is not large enough to sustain many sellers. The CJD and BSE scare could even spread to dairy products and if this happened, cow farmers would cease to exist entirely.
However, when people cease to eat beef what do they eat instead? The answer is pork, lamb and other meats. There are several reasons why people in the UK might cease to eat beef. For example, everyone may suddenly become vegetarian or tastes may alter in such a way that nobody in the UK wants to eat beef. However, these occurrences are at best unlikely. The only plausible reason for people in the UK to cease to eat beef is the disease CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease). This disease is the human equivalent of 'Mad Cow Disease' or BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy).

In recent years, there has been a huge increase in the number of cases of BSE. This seems to be mainly caused by farming methods from 20 years ago. In the 1960s and 1970s, cows were given feed which included sheep (and their brains) in its ingredients. Many animals which ate this feed developed BSE and even more passed it on to their young.

There is a belief among the people of the UK that eating beef is dangerous, as they believe that the BSE can be passed on to humans when they eat beef. However, there is no scientific evidence at present to suggest that this is the case. Nevertheless, cases of CJD and BSE have been widely documented in the media and this has greatly influenced people. Pictures on television of cows with BSE who are unable to walk properly and humans with CJD highlight how horrific and debilitating a condition CJD is. If the media coverage of CJD and BSE continues in the same manner, it is not inconceivable that people in the UK might be so scared that they cease to eat beef entirely.

If people in the UK were to cease to eat beef, the effect on the agricultural industry would be devastating. Cow farmers would fall in numbers by a huge amount. This is because with the beef market destroyed, the only market open to these farmers would be the dairy products market, which is not large enough to sustain many sellers. The CJD and BSE scare could even spread to dairy products, and if this happened, cow farmers would cease to exist entirely.

However, when people cease to eat beef, what do they eat instead? The answer is pork, lamb, and other meats. The increase in demand for other meats would be approximately proportionate to the fall in demand for beef, meaning that producers of other meats would benefit from people ceasing to eat beef.

After a few reported cases of CJD, a similar form of the disease found in humans, it is known that "mad-cow disease" (BSE) is the cause. Researchers believe that eating beef containing offal will transmit the fatal disease to humans.

This claim has devastated the British beef industry, as people are now too scared to eat beef in case they contract the illness. Already, the sales of beef in America have dropped by about 15%, and in Britain, they have dropped by about 6% to 7%.

Although scientists say that to contract CJD, part of the cow's offal must be contained within the beef. Customers are still reluctant to eat the meat in case it has come from some "dodgy" butcher trying to cut costs. As you can imagine, this has had a tremendous influence on sales in places such as fast-food restaurants where beef burgers are the main item on the menu. An example of one is McDonald's, where they have immediately brought out a notice stating that their beef burgers are made from 100% of the finest, pure beef and contain no offal.

In my view, no decent restaurant with a good reputation would risk buying poor beef in case a customer caught CJD and managed to trace it back to the restaurant. An outcome like this would mean they would be sued for several thousand pounds and would probably have to sell up.

There is widespread concern throughout the country over the publication of the Jakob Creutzfeldt-Jakobs disease or British beef. This issue is not only affecting the agricultural industry but also the meat industry as a whole. The disease has been linked with many deaths throughout the UK, and its publication has gradually brought the sales of British beef to a standstill.

There has been no attempt by the government to reveal the truth about the disease, even though it has found that a vegetarian who has never been in contact with beef contracted the human form of 'mad cow disease' and died. This is one of the reasons why people are not buying beef or local butchers. People are scared of the consequences and the possibility of contracting the disease, although there is no concrete evidence that humans can actually contract the disease from the meat.

Beef has been given bad publicity by the press, and it is becoming a major concern with the public. There was also a similar problem over salmonella in eggs, which nearly brought an end to the sales of eggs throughout the country because of bad publicity by the press. People were scared of purchasing eggs in case they contracted salmonella poisoning, but there was no concrete proof. The industry eventually picked up again, but it took a long time.

The publicity of 'mad cow disease' means that farmers are having to be more aware of the condition of their cattle. It is only the older cattle that are able to contract the disease, but it does mean that the cattle must be checked and destroyed if they are found to have the disease.

People in the UK may be put off eating beef due to the mad cow disease scares that are circulating in the news. Little is known about the effects this disease can have on humans, if there are any. The public are not aware if the beef they are eating is contaminated or not. If it is contaminated, it may affect them, but only in the long term, or it may be irradiated during the cooking process. Too little is known at this stage due to the relatively recent introduction of BSE.

If the market for beef drops in the UK, there could be a drastic effect on agriculture as a whole. If people stop eating beef, there will be a surplus of cows in the UK. They would have to be slaughtered and wasted, unless they can be sold abroad. Veal is sold abroad, so as long as foreigners are not afraid of BSE, beef can still be sold.

If people did not eat beef, it is likely they would stop eating anything associated with beef, such as milk and therefore cheese. All dairy product sales would decrease, farmers would go bust, products would be wasted, and farmers would be after subsidies.
